data.title: Yum! Brands: A Check-In On The Value-Oriented Consumer Ahead Of Earnings
data.description:
Yum! Brands, Inc. (YUM) will report Q3 FY25 earnings pre-market on Tuesday, November 4th. Going into earnings, I am slightly bullish, but not expecting any huge movement. I will be looking for Pizza Hut and Taco Bell to maintain momentum or show modest improvements, and KFC’s international segment to show steady unit growth. Shares are currently trading around $140 and appear to have expectations for modest growth already baked in. The key topics to watch will be around value menu demand, margin pressure from labor inflation, and tech stack execution.

Setup

Yum will release earnings at 7:00 a.m. EST, Tuesday, November 4th, followed by a conference call at 8:15 a.m. EST. Yum stock has stayed relatively flat since its last earnings call, and is up around 5% since the start of the year. Going into the release, consensus estimate EPS of $1.49, revenue of $1.94B, and sales growth of 5%.

Company Snapshot

Yum! Brands is the company behind Taco Bell, KFC, Pizza Hut, and Habit Burger. They operate over 61,000 franchised and company-owned restaurants (98% franchised). Last year, Yum returned $7.57B in revenue with KFC accounting for $3.10B (41%), followed by Taco Bell with $2.86B (38%), Pizza Hut with $1.01B (13%), and The Habit Burger Grill with $600M (8%). In Q2, digital system sales surpassed $9B. This marked an increase to 57% digital mix of orders. Customers are increasingly choosing to pivot toward the higher-margin mobile, delivery, and pickup channels. Yum’s strength compared to their peers like Restaurant Brands International (QSR) and McDonald’s (MCD) is in their steady growth and new store expansion, but their margins are thinner than those of their competitors.

What To Watch

  • KFC International Pipeline: After KFC opened over 550 new locations in Q2 across 58 countries, it will be important to listen for commentary on 2026 openings, specifically in Asia and Latin America. International expansion is crucial for measuring franchise partners' confidence in Yum! Brands.

  • Same-Store Sales: Market will be looking for KFC to expand unit sales at a solid pace and for Taco Bell to post small same-store sales growth in line with past quarters. Value promotions are expected to increase now and will be necessary for traffic to hold up.

  • Tech Efficiency: Watch for commentary on the rollout of “Byte by Yum!”, Yum’s internal AI system, to see if their investment in AI is accelerating labor or delivery-cost efficiencies.

  • Commodity Cost: Last quarter inflation on protein, cheese, and labor was a stumbling block for Yum. Watch for a lift in margins from a greater digital mix.

My view is that Yum’s near-term performance will rely on how effectively it manages price-value perceptions amid a cautious US consumer. A key value in protecting this perception will be Taco Bell’s value menu remaining a key traffic driver. Additionally, I believe success in KFC’s international expansion will be necessary for offsetting potentially modest domestic softness. A major long-term growth driver in the business will be margin improvements driven by easing input costs, growing digital mix, and AI implementation. Management’s commentary on "Byte by Yum!" will be key in driving this sentiment. Evidence of early labor efficiencies or order throughput from AI integration will majorly help in seeing the long-term growth story at Yum. The defensive nature of Yum’s brands gives confidence that there is limited downside risk going into earnings. To see any meaningful upside, Yum would likely need to report same-store sales growth greater than 3% and stronger than expected international unit growth.

Context Going Into Earnings

In Yum’s last earnings call for Q2 FY25, Yum reported total sales growth of 4%. Taco Bell’s same-store sales grew 4% and KFC 5%. They mentioned that the consumer value was a priority and that supply chain pressures were easing steadily. The key question going into Q3 will be whether Yum can maintain their same-store sales momentum despite consumer price sensitivity.

Despite the quick-service restaurant industry experiencing a 3.4% decline year over year, Yum has been able to maintain steady sales growth. This perseverance highlights the strength of pricing power in its leading brands. Yum! Brands are likely capturing share from smaller operators, evidenced by the negative transaction counts of US quick-service peers. Yum has been able to preserve profitability even in these periods of soft volume due to their combination of scale, franchising model, and strong brand equity. These qualities separate Yum from their peers and are justification for its premium valuation to their restaurant peers.

Valuation

Using a discounted cash flow approach with a 6.8% WACC and a 2.25% terminal growth rate, I estimate Yum! Brands’ intrinsic value is at $173 per share. This represents a roughly 24% upside from the current share price of $139.

I calculated a 6.8% WACC reflecting Yum’s roughly 76% equity and 24% debt capital structure, a beta of 0.72, and a 4.0% risk-free rate. I applied a market risk premium of 3.85%, consistent with mature US consumer discretionary peers. I used a 4.33% pre-tax cost of debt and a 15% effective tax rate, in line with the company’s historical filings and guidance. Finally, I assumed a 2.25% terminal growth rate to reflect the long-term inflation and global GDP growth expectations relevant to a diversified fast food operator.

The revenue growth assumptions of 6% falling to 5% by 2029 reflect moderate international expansion and steady system sales. I assume EBIT margins are rising from 34% up to 36% as Yum recognizes operational efficiencies from AI and leverage from digital ordering becoming more popular. Capital Expenditures, depreciation, and changes in NWC were modeled at 3%, 2%, and 1% of sales, respectively, consistent with Yum’s asset-light, franchise structure.

Currently, Yum trades at $139. Based on my DCF calculations, I believe the fair value is near $170-$180 per share. The sensitivity analysis shows an intrinsic value ranging from $150 - $190 under reasonable adjustments to the discount rate and terminal growth rate.

This valuation supports a moderate buy rating. Yum has a solid base for long-term compounding formed by their durable franchise cash flows and growing digital sales mix. The key factor from this point in getting Yum to reach this price target will be dependent on management’s ability to sustain same-store sales growth and margin gains across KFC, Taco Bell, and Pizza Hut’s international segments.

Yum currently trades at 28x earnings, close to Restaurant Brands International’s multiple, operator of chains like Popeyes and Burger King, and below the premium valuation of McDonald’s and Chipotle. At this current valuation, the market is confident in Yum’s steady earnings growth and global scale. Their valuation reflects slower anticipated near-term growth compared to the higher multiple peers like Chipotle. Pricing is consistent with expectations for mid-single-digit sales growth and stable margins. There is an opportunity surprise on the upside through digital efficiencies or an outperformance in their international expansion.

Company Ticker Market Cap ($B) P/E (TTM) EV/EBITDA (NTM) Dividend Yield
Yum! Brands (YUM) $39B 28x 20x 2.0%
Restaurant Brands Intl. (QSR) $35B 24x 18x 3.2%
McDonald's Corp (MCD) $200B 30x 22x 2.3%
Chipotle (CMG) $70B 44x 26x --
Starbucks (SBUX) $110B 25x 17x 2.8%

Where It Could Go Wrong

Going into this earnings call, the biggest risk to Yum’s near-term outlook comes from a potential weaker-than-expected same-store print or a slowdown in international demand. A softer consumer could limit unit expansion, especially in emerging markets where Yum has been most aggressive. Margin pressure caused by delays or lack of success in the rollout of “Byte by Yum!” or commodity/labor inflation remains a concern. Additionally, foreign exchange volatility or regulatory hurdles will be important to watch as they could negatively impact unit growth and overall profitability.

Macro Read-Through

Yum’s earnings report will provide useful information in understanding the health of the value-oriented US consumer. In a recent report from Deloitte, they found that consumers' financial confidence was decreasing, and they were choosing to make more selective spending decisions. In an article from The Washington Post, they noted that lower-income Americans were sharply trimming spending. The overall economy and consumer spending are more reliant on the top percentage of earners.

Yum serves consumers who are focused on value. Their earnings print will give us a look into whether broader consumer stress is now creeping in. Taco Bell and KFC delivering resilient consumer traffic and spend would suggest value dining remains a durable corner of consumer behavior. Any signs of weakness in their report may reinforce the idea of widening pressure on middle and lower-income households. This would have implications on not just Yum, but also platforms like DoorDash and similar value restaurant chains.

Bottom Line

Yum! Brands is going into this earnings report with expectations largely priced in. Expect the stock to remain near current levels if management delivers steady same-store sales growth with steady margins. A surprise to the upside will likely be dependent on progress in digital efficiencies or better-than-expected international unit sales. For long-term investors, Yum remains a durable source of consistent cash generation, with future performance mostly tied to operational execution rather than a re-rating opportunity.

data.title: Maran Capital Management Q3 2025 Letter
data.description:
Dear Partners and Friends,

In the third quarter, the partnership returned +1.4%, net of all fees and expenses, bringing the year-to-date net return to +11.0% and the one-year trailing net return to +18.1%.1 Our intermediate and longer-term compounded average growth rates (CAGRs) have been solid as well.

If you missed it, we published a variety of materials over the summer to celebrate our firm’s 10th anniversary. You can find them on our website. As of the end of the third quarter, our firm’s assets under management (AUM) were approximately $47 million. Welcome, new partners.

Explore/Exploit: Going Rogue

Ants and bees are both members of the order Hymenoptera, whose members are typically eusocial, cooperative insects that live in large colonies that can be viewed as superorganisms. When an ant finds an attractive source of food, it leaves a pheromone trail on its way back to its nest that other ants can follow. Bees use a different strategy to alert their compatriots to good finds. They fly back to the hive and do what entomologists have dubbed a “waggle dance.”2 Through these elaborate dances, bees give their peers directions to a field of newly bloomed flowers (or maybe to a picnic table after a five-year-old’s birthday party).

But if every ant simply followed the strongest pheromone trail to the best food source, that food source would eventually run out, and the ant colony would be at a loss. And if every bee simply followed the directions imparted by the most dynamic waggle dance, a beehive would likewise exhaust this resource.

Fortunately, some ants and bees have a rogue streak. These intrepid individuals will deviate—veer off from the pheromone trail or shun the directions of the waggle dance—and seek fortune and glory on their own in search of new sources of nectar, honeydew, syrup, or sap.

Evolution through natural selection has fine-tuned this balance; most ants and bees follow the proverbial herd (or, in this case, swarm, hive, colony, or army) and target a known food source. But a smaller group will launch out on their own and seek novel sources of food.3

Rory Sutherland, Vice Chairman of advertising agency Ogilvy, discussed this in his fun, wide-ranging book, Alchemy: The Dark Art and Curious Science of Creating Magic in Brands, Business, and Life:

There is a parallel in the behaviour of bees, which do not make the most of the system they have evolved to collect nectar and pollen. Although they have an efficient way of communicating about the direction of reliable food sources, the waggle dance, a significant proportion of the hive seems to ignore it altogether and journeys off at random. In the short term, the hive would be better off if all bees slavishly followed the waggle dance, and for a time this random behaviour baffled scientists, who wondered why 20 million years of bee evolution had not enforced a greater level of behavioural compliance. However, what they discovered was fascinating: without these rogue bees, the hive would get stuck in what complexity theorists call ‘a local maximum’; they would be so efficient at collecting food from known sources that, once these existing sources of food dried up, they wouldn’t know where to go next and the hive would starve to death. So the rogue bees are, in a sense, the hive’s research and development function, and their inefficiency pays off handsomely when they discover a fresh source of food. It is precisely because they do not concentrate exclusively on short-term efficiency that bees have survived so many million years.4

The manner in which ants and bees divide their resources is among a class of ideas that have been dubbed explore/exploit problems by zoologists, economists, and computer scientists.5 Questions related to these problems and their cousins—optimal stopping problems—range from the personal to scientific to corporate realms.

How much time should one spend exploring for new sources of food, information, or ideas before shifting to exploiting the current best source? Should one remain in the dating pool or pop the question and seek to settle down? Should a company continue to refine a product or launch it as it is? How much should be spent on R&D in search of new drug candidates vs. on marketing existing products? And as in the classic framing of one optimal stopping problem, how many potential secretaries6 should one interview before making one an offer of employment?

Of course, portfolio managers are faced with similar types of questions. We must determine how we allocate one finite resource—time—between exploring for new investment ideas (and new types of investment ideas) and monitoring, researching, and generally sticking with (exploiting) our existing strategies and positions. Should we follow the herd or veer off on our own? Just how patient should we be with what we have? We must also determine how to allocate another finite resource—our current capital base—amongst a plethora of potential investments. Leverage, cash balances, correlation, and position sizing all factor into the decisions.

While economists have come up with optimized algorithms for certain modeled scenarios—the Gittins index, for example, or the 37% rule for the secretary problem—the real world is messy and, as you may have suspected, as analytical as I may be, I do not believe in an algorithmic approach to research, position sizing, or portfolio management.

Wide Funnel, High Bar

Unlike bees, we investors can spend the majority of our time exploring for new investment ideas while simultaneously “exploiting” our existing positions. Sure, we must spend time monitoring and doing ongoing research on our holdings, but at least in a concentrated portfolio like ours, we are left with a lot of time to be on the hunt. I am frequently asked about my approach to sourcing new ideas. The top of our funnel is very broad. I do small amounts of reading, research, and valuation work on a large number of companies. But the real meat of our process comes in the middle of the proverbial funnel—the winnowing down of potential investments from a large list of possibilities to a small, concentrated portfolio of best ideas.

I have been investing for my entire career—over 20 years now—so there are many companies, sectors, management teams, and business models that I know well or am familiar with. In addition to following many of these on an ongoing basis, I study many new special situations and event-driven setups as they arise: mergers, spin-offs, reverse-Morris Trust transactions, tenders, rights offerings, and various other sources of corporate change (and thus potential for mis-valuation and catalysts). I am well versed in special situations research, which frequently involves studying proxies, S-1s, S-3s, 8-Ks, 10-Ks, 13Ds, Section 16 filings, PACER filings, and the rest of the alphabet soup of regulatory filings that apply.

There are elements to our top-of-the-funnel process that are systematic: The review of various classes of special situations, for example. But like rogue ants and bees, I allow for a large amount of room for serendipity and following my nose. We are not investing in the same types of investments as most funds.

While the top of our funnel is wide and allows for variation, the bar for a stock’s inclusion in the portfolio is always very high. When interviewing secretaries, it is unlikely that one will be a hundred times better than others; after getting a feel for the field, one can make a decision and offer a job. But in investing, a fantastic investment can indeed be orders of magnitude better than an average one, so it is worth having a certain amount of patience. On the flip side, our bar can’t be so high that nothing ever meets it. The perfect is the enemy of the good enough.

We therefore utilize the concept of a threshold approach: As I have previously discussed, we typically underwrite for an expected IRR of at least 25% (I have famed this as seeking “three-year doubles” or better) with limited risk of permanent capital loss on the downside. While it is easy to focus on the first half of this target (the threshold IRR), the second half (limited downside) is every bit as important. This is why you will tend to see less levered (or net cash) companies in our portfolio. You will also see quality, growth, modest valuations, and, frequently, catalysts.

A mid-20s IRR is a high bar, and to be clear, we don’t necessarily expect to generate fund-level returns at that rate. We strive to generate excellent risk-adjusted returns, but we’ll invariably get some stocks wrong along the way or some stocks will take longer than we think to achieve fair value. But by aiming high, we have achieved a ~20% annualized gross return (and therefore mid-to-high teens net return, depending on share class) since inception.7

Market Backdrop & Portfolio Update

Our top five positions as of the end of the quarter were Clarus Corp (CLAR), Correios de Portugal, S.A. (Euronext Lisbon: CTT)(OTCPK:CTTPY)(OTCPK:CTTOF), Horizon Kinetics Holding Corporation (OTCPK:HKHC), Turning Point Brands (TPB), and an undisclosed position.8 You will find none of these companies in broad market indices such as the S&P 500.

IPO and capital markets activity—including the return of SPACs—has picked up, and there are pockets of froth in the market. A major investment bank recently distributed a list of “meme” stocks; it was comprised of more than 60 companies. AI, quantum, nuclear, rare earth, and space-related stocks are attracting significant speculative capital, regardless of business model quality. As usual, we have no “fear of missing out” (FOMO) on these types of stocks. There is always something we are missing out on, and we are okay with that. There are enough attractively priced companies in the market outside of the bubble areas. We have demonstrated that we can generate solid returns while generally avoiding tech and other trendy sectors.

Meme stocks and momentum sectors aside, even many of the highest quality companies in the market do not appear to be inexpensive. Remember, investing is not simply about identifying the best companies. It is easy to note that (at least six of) the Magnificent Seven companies are dominant in their fields. The important question for those that own these stocks, though, is whether they are attractively priced.

Steve Mandel, who runs the hedge fund Lone Pine, has been quoted as saying, “I don’t need an analyst to tell me whether a 10x PE stock is cheap; I need one to tell me whether a 40x PE stock is cheap.” We can flip this framing: We don’t need analysts to tell us whether a 40x PE company is quality or growing or loved; we should ask whether a single digit PE stock is quality or growing or can one day be loved. When we find one of these (like APi Group (APG), Turning Point Brands (TPB), or Cadre Holdings (CDRE), among others in our portfolio), I get excited.

As I caution in most letters, our portfolio may behave quite differently than the broader market indices over the short term (especially during periods of bubbles and froth in the markets). Unfortunately, we are going through a period this month in which our fund is down while various market indices are up. Several of our core positions have pulled back not due to ascertainable fundamental reasons, but seemingly on account of motivated sellers (perhaps, in some cases, mutual fund tax loss sellers ahead of their fiscal year-ends).

I view this recent weakness as an opportunity. I believe our portfolio is attractive and that a number of our core positions have upcoming catalysts. With the appropriate long-term time horizon, I’m confident in our portfolio and approach.

I have been working hard on a new idea over the past few quarters, and this position is now in our top five. While I cannot yet discuss it publicly, I look forward to sharing more on this investment in my next letter.

Conclusion

Long-term clients, as well as those who joined in the last quarter: Thank you. I truly appreciate your trust and support. Your alignment and long-term orientation allow me to invest in the manner that I believe will maximize our risk-adjusted returns. I look forward to writing to you again in the new year. In the meantime, don’t hesitate to reach out if you would like to discuss any aspect of the partnership.

Sincerely,

Dan Roller

1 Net returns based on the fund’s standard fee share class. Individual partner returns may vary based on share class and timing of investment, among other factors. Please refer to individual account statements for more detail. Please see page 6 for important disclaimers, and our investor presentation for complete monthly results since inception.

2 These waggle dances may sound familiar to die-hard value investors as Charlie Munger referred to the behavior in his speech, “The Psychology of Human Misjudgment,” to elucidate what he called, “say-something” syndrome. Here is a link to a reprint of the speech. While the whole thing is worth re-reading, you can find the section I’m referring to by searching the speech for the term “honeybee.”

3 This description of the phenomenon (Rogue bees! Intrepid ants!), while compelling, is not exactly right. Closer to the truth: Waggle dances can only be so precise; pheromone trails wear out; some ants or bees just get lost or distracted. But one way or another, these groups split their resources between harvesting a known food source and searching for new ones.

4 Source

5 For further good discussion of this and related topics, I enjoyed Algorithms to Live By: The Computer Science of Human Decisions by Brian Christian and Tom Griffiths.

6 The secretary problem’s roots trace to at least 1949 (if not prior to that, in various forms), which explains the less politically correct—yet most well-known—name of the problem. I has also been referred to as the marriage problem and the best choice problem.

7 Please see page 6 for important disclaimers and our investor presentation for complete monthly results since inception.

8 Listed alphabetically.

Disclaimer

This document is not an offer to sell or a solicitation to buy interests in any partnership (“Fund”), even if such interests may be currently offered to others. Any such offering will be made only in accordance with the Fund’s Confidential Offering Memorandum (the “Offering Memorandum”). Investors should be prepared to suffer losses of their entire investments. The Offering Memorandum contains brief descriptions of certain of the risks associated with investing in the Fund. Certain information contained in this document constitutes “forward-looking statements,” which can be identified by the use of forward-looking terminology such as “may,” “will,” “should,” “expect,” “anticipate,” “target,” “intend,” “continue” or “believe,” or the negatives thereof or other variations thereon or comparable terminology. Due to various risks and uncertainties, actual events or results or the actual performance of the Partnership described herein may differ materially from those reflected or contemplated in such forward-looking statements. Funds managed by Maran Capital Management, LLC (“MCM”) may have an investment in the companies discussed in this document. It is possible that MCM may change its opinion regarding the companies at any time for any or no reason. MCM may buy, sell, sell short, cover, change the form of its investment, or completely exit from its investment in the companies at any time for any or no reason. None of the information contained herein has been filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, any securities administrator under any state securities laws, or any other U.S. or non-U.S. governmental or self-regulatory authority. No governmental authority has passed on the merits of this offering or the adequacy of the information contained herein. Any representation to the contrary is unlawful. Prices for securities discussed are closing prices as of October 10, 2025 unless otherwise noted and are not representative of the prices paid by the fund for those securities. Positions reflected in this letter do not represent all of the positions held, purchased, and/or sold, and may represent a small percentage of holdings and/or activity. Fund returns reflect the gross or net investment results (as labeled) of a single capital contribution at the beginning of the period with no subsequent capital contributions or withdrawals. Gross results indicates the gross return of the partnership before the application of any management fees or fund expenses. Net results reflect the accrual of all expenses and compensation to the investment manager for an investor with a 1% management fee and a 20% incentive fee (Standard), 1% management fee and 15% incentive fee (“5-year lockup” terms), and 1% incentive fee and 10% incentive fee (“Founder’s” terms). Some investors have fee structures that are different from those currently being offered. Results are estimates only and are subject to year-end audit. In 3Q 2025, the return of the S&P 500 was +8.1%, and the return of the Russell 2000 was +12.4%; year-to-date, these indices were +14.8% and +10.2%, respectively. The S&P 500 and Russell 2000 are indices of US equities. They are included for informational purposes only and are not representative of the type of investments made by the fund. The fund’s investments differ materially from these indices. The fund is concentrated in a small number of positions while the indices are diversified. R2000-TR is the total return of the Russell 2000 Index with dividends reinvested. The Russell 2000 is and index of US equities. It is included for informational purposes only and may not be representative of the type of investments made by the fund. The fund’s investments differ materially from this index. The fund is concentrated in a small number of positions while the index is diversified. Results are for the periods indicated through September 30, 2025. The fund was launched (fund launch) with $500k of the manager’s capital on June 1, 2015. Inception* (Inception of outside capital) is defined as the period beginning January 1, 2016, when the first $100k of outside capital was invested into the fund. Please see our investor presentation for complete monthly net and gross results since inception. Year-to-date 2025 returns are pending audit and subject to revision. Past performance is not indicative of future results. Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Zurn Elkay Water Solutions Doubled My Money, But I'm Downgrading Anyway
data.description:
Thesis

A couple of years ago, I started covering Zurn Elkay Water Solutions (ZWS), a Milwaukee-based company that designs and makes plumbing and water management systems for commercial, institutional, and industrial buildings. I rated the stock a Buy back then. I like companies like ZWS. They’re straightforward, easy to follow, and kind of old-school in this fast-paced AI era. At the time, I thought the company’s stock price was in a good spot compared to its long-term potential, thanks to rising demand for clean water infrastructure and the early benefits of the Zurn–Elkay merger.

Since my call, ZWS has been one of the best movers in my portfolio, and hopefully yours too, gaining about 135% compared to roughly 66% for the S&P 500 (SP500). But after such a big run, it’s fair to ask whether ZWS still has more room to grow.

After looking at the latest Q3 results, my research suggests that Zurn Elkay’s strong fundamentals, including wider profit margins, solid cash flow, and policy-driven demand for safe water infrastructure, point to a sustainable growth story. However, the company’s stock price now already reflects much of that strength and success.

Zurn Elkay’s Q3 Highlights: Growth, Margins, and Momentum

By and large this quarter, it looked like Zurn Elkay did well in the areas it could directly manage and held steady where the market just wouldn’t budge, as the overall business climate was slow and steady.

In that setting, the results come in with revenue reported at $455 million, that's up 11% from last year, with core growth also at 11%.

EPS was $0.43, about three cents higher than expected. Adjusted EBITDA rose 16% to $122 million. Meanwhile, the profit margin widened by 120 basis points to 26.8%, the highest quarterly margin since the Elkay merger.

On the call, management said the results came from higher volume and the steady daily grind of the Zurn Elkay Business System. Pricing added about five percentage points, and unit volumes grew too, which is a good tell that indicates that real demand is present and not just higher prices that's driving these results. At the same time, about $8 million in customer orders were moved up into September ahead of a planned price increase. Even so, management said their guidance assumes that timing will balance out in the fourth quarter, not artificially boost the growth rate.

Nonresidential business stayed strong, while residential stayed weak. That might sound typical, but you have to keep in mind that Zurn Elkay has a bigger presence in education, health care, and public spaces, and these are areas where drinking water solutions are now seen as required items. In other words, state rules are turning into real purchase orders, which drives steady demand in those segments.

Take Michigan’s Filter First law. It set aside $50 million for schools and child care centers, with hard deadlines to finish the job. A statewide grant program has also been established in the state of New Jersey, which establishes precise timetables for guidance, bidding, and installation. Operationally, the point is that these programs build deadline-driven, budgeted demand that isn’t tied to new construction, and naturally, they're going to favor those suppliers already certified and on site.

The company’s profits and cash generation seemed to be the main drivers this quarter. Free cash flow came in at $94 million. So far this year, sales have increased by $93 million, and EBITDA has gone up by $39 million, meaning about 42% of the extra sales turned into profit. The year-to-date EBITDA margin is also up by 1.2 percentage points, on top of 8% core growth, and that's exactly the kind of improvement I want to see when overall market demand isn’t providing much help.

Net leverage dropped to just 0.6x, the lowest level since the company went public, which buys optionality. During the quarter, the company bought back $25 million worth of its own stock, bringing the year-to-date total to $135 million, which equals about 3.8% of all shares.

It also raised its dividend by 22% (see FAST Graphs data above) and renewed its stock buyback program, authorizing up to $500 million more. Essentially, by shutting down its U.S. pension plan and shedding roughly $200 million in liabilities, the company simplified its balance sheet and made future management easier.

Zurn Elkay: Pricing Discipline and Regulatory Fit

Having noted that, costs have gone up. Back in August, new rules added a 50% tariff on some partly processed copper imports. And because of that, management now expects to pay around $50 million in tariffs; that's higher than their earlier estimate of around $35–45 million. Despite that, the company acted early to offset this. It raised list prices in April, which affected the entire next quarter, and made another adjustment in mid-September to update rates for each country and for copper materials.

On the call, the CFO explained that the price benefit should show up in the first half of next year, which will help revenues during those quarters. Keep in mind, those price increases don’t boost results overnight; it takes a bit for them to fully flow through the numbers, so the first half of 2026 will likely look stronger as the effects of those higher prices continue to show up. By the second half of 2026, that effect will fade. After a full year of higher prices, it just becomes the new normal.

Nevertheless, let's go back to the regulation environment since the company's product features and government rules worked together in a good way. If you aren't aware, schools and districts require filters that meet NSF/ANSI Standard 53 for removing lead and Standard 42 for improving taste and removing particles. In certain cases, some bid lists also ask for Standards 372 and 401, which deal with low lead content and microplastic removal. Elkay’s main bottle fillers and filters already meet all these standards. My read, which is grounded in the numbers we just went over, is that once customers standardize on Zurn Elkay’s systems, they tend to stay there. Therefore, when new funding shows up, the buying happens fast—no long comparison shopping, just orders.

Elkay Pro Filtration gained early success because its filters are quicker to install and last longer. I'd argue that that could be a big help for maintenance teams already stretched thin while trying to meet safety rules across many locations. Liv EZ, the new built-in water bottle filler for homes, is a smaller side project. The company isn’t depending on home sales for growth, but this product brings Elkay’s strong commercial-grade filtration into homes, where people already know and trust the brand from places like schools and offices.

Balanced Outlook for 2025

Moving on to the company’s outlook, it does strike a balance between optimism and caution. In the first nine months, order rates were just slightly higher than shipments, and management expects the fourth quarter to be about even, meaning they plan to produce only what customers actually need, not oversupply distributors. As for the fourth quarter, the company's projecting core sales growth in the high single digits and adjusted earnings (EBITDA) between $99 million and $102 million.

For the full year, the company expects about 8% growth in core sales, EBITDA between $437 million and $440 million, and more than $300 million in free cash flow. The overall message seems to fit the broader economy; that is, commercial construction isn’t booming, and financing remains tight, but I'd say that the company’s own growth drivers are strong enough to keep business steadily building even without a surge in new projects.

Zurn Elkay’s Valuation

At the current share price, ZWS is trading at a P/E ratio of 33.6, and even looking ahead, the forward P/E is 31.5.

That’s quite a bit higher than the typical industrial company’s 21 and even above its own five-year average of around 28.

The same pattern shows up in other measures too, with the EV-to-EBITDA ratio at 18.4, compared with about 12.7 for the sector; the EV-to-sales ratio is 4.78 versus 2.18, and the forward price-to-cash-flow is 24.8, while peers sit near 16.4.

The dividend yield is under 1%, so income investors won’t get much comfort there. That is to say, from that angle, the market seems happy to pay a steep price for what it sees as quality, stability, and government-supported growth, and then tack on an extra layer of optimism for good management.

FAST Graphs throws on some more cold water. Its model says the fair value is around $21.43, which is less than half the current price, and it even shows a potential annual loss of about 22.5% if the stock drifts back to a more “normal” P/E ratio of 26.4.

Analysts’ forecasts help ease some of that risk, but they don’t make it go away. EPS is anticipated to increase by 14.6% in 2025, then drop down to 9.4% in 2026 and 8.4% in 2027, before rising up again to 18.5% in 2028, according to Wall Street's projections. If that plays out, how much investors make overall will depend more on where that P/E ratio ends up than on the actual growth in earnings.

Final Takeaway

After a strong run the past couple of years, I’m moving ZWS to a Hold. Despite the fact that the company's performance and long-term prognosis are strong, the premium price of the stock already bakes in a significant portion of the company's strength. It could still be a good buy if earnings pick up or state-funded filtration demand grows faster than expected.

data.title: Thornburg Core Plus Bond Fund Q3 2025 Commentary
data.description:
Despite volatility, our focus continues to be on generating attractive income and risk-adjusted total returns over the long term.

Market Review

Markets showed resilience despite effective tariff rates increasing sevenfold since the beginning of the year, while the current administration announced several new protectionist measures including 100% tariffs on foreign-made movies, substantial tariffs on imported furniture, and potential requirements for semiconductor manufacturers to match foreign production with domestic output. Trade uncertainty was partially mitigated by reciprocal tariff arrangements, a 90-day postponement on China tariffs, and bilateral deals. The Federal Reserve began its rate cutting cycle with a 25 basis point reduction in September, with updated projections indicating an additional 50 basis points of cuts expected before year end. Concerns about Fed independence surfaced when the administration announced plans to fire Fed Governor Cook over alleged mortgage fraud.

Treasury yields fluctuated throughout the period, with short-end yields declining approximately 30-40 basis points as rate-cut expectations increased. The curve steepened with the 30-year yield falling 7 basis points since the start of the quarter. Despite weakening labor market indicators, including the narrowest labor market differential since early 2021 in the September Consumer Confidence survey, economic data remained positive, supporting narratives of consumer resilience, improved trade clarity, and stronger corporate capital expenditure. As the quarter ended, the federal government faced an imminent shutdown with no funding deal reached by September 30.

Third Quarter 2025 Performance Highlights

  • In 3Q25 the portfolio (I share class) returned 2.34%, 31 basis points ahead of the Bloomberg U.S. Universal Index. Year to date the portfolio (I share class) returned 6.57%, 44 basis points ahead of the index.
  • Sector allocation and security selection contributed positively to relative outperformance with the portfolio’s treasury underweight and security selection within corporate bonds providing uplift of 11 and 6 basis points, respectively. Specifically, the portfolio’s security selection within corporates and CMO’s resulted in strong contributions to relative performance.
  • The portfolio maintained an average duration of 6.27 versus 6.03 for the index with the overweight duration and yield curve positioning contributing 4 basis points from relative performance for the quarter. Rates across the board fell in Q3 and the curve continued to steepen with short-end rates falling 30-40 basis points and the long end falling 8-10 basis points.

Current Positioning and Outlook

The strategy remained positioned with a longer duration and higher quality bias compared to its long-term range, driven by attractive real yields and tight credit spreads. Security selection, driven by our bottom-up fundamental credit research, was a key contributor, allowing us to identify resilient issuers across various sectors and industries. Corporate credit spreads tightened significantly, approaching levels not seen since the 1990s, and we remain cautious on adding incremental credit risk as the compensation for doing so remains near historic lows. Real yields remain attractive relative to history, compensating investors for fiscal largesse, government dysfunction (shutdowns), and persistent inflation. While nimbleness around duration positioning remains important, interest rate volatility has been trending lower, perhaps suppressed by reduced government data flow.

We maintained broad diversification across fixed-income sectors with an emphasis on sectors demonstrating resilience or offering compelling risk/reward profiles identified through our research. The allocations to investment grade corporate credit and mortgage pass- throughs were large drivers of absolute returns during the period, however falling yields led to Treasuries outperforming.

Looking ahead, the global economy has shown surprising resilience despite mounting pressures from the delayed impact of tariffs and constrained fiscal flexibility. Additionally, the Fed must balance relatively persistent inflation with downside risks to the labor market alongside uncertainty surrounding the independence of the country’s institutions. With flexible mandates across many of our fixed income strategies—enabling us to dynamically adjust duration, credit exposure, and sector allocation—we remain positioned to take advantage of potential bouts of heightened volatility.
